title: 104_s2088
content: The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" allows for a credit for employer expenses for child care assistance under the new section 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" introduces a credit for employer-provided child care expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit is 50% of qualified child care expenditures, not exceeding $150,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include costs for property used as a child care facility. The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" allows a credit for employer-provided child care expenses, including costs for property used as a qualified child care facility. This includes operating costs such as employee training, scholarship programs, and increased compensation for employees with child care training. The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" allows a credit for employer-provided child care expenses, including costs related to employee training, scholarship programs, and increased compensation for employees with child care training. This applies to qualified child care facilities that provide dependent care assistance. A qualified child care facility, as defined by the "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996," is a facility that provides dependent care assistance and complies with state or local laws, including licensing requirements. The facility must be open for enrollment to be considered a qualified child care facility for tax purposes. A qualified child care facility must be open for enrollment to employees of the taxpayer, not the taxpayer's main business unless 30% of enrollees are employees' dependents, and cannot discriminate in favor of highly compensated employees. The text discusses the requirements for a qualified child care facility, including being open to all employees of the taxpayer, not discriminating in favor of highly compensated employees, and potential recapture of credits if there is a recapture event. The text outlines the recapture rules for qualified child care expenditures, including the applicable recapture percentage determined from a specific table. The recapture rules for qualified child care expenditures include a table with applicable recapture percentages based on the year of recapture event. The recapture rules for qualified child care expenditures involve a table with recapture percentages based on the year of the recapture event. Year 1 starts when the child care facility is put into service by the taxpayer. A recapture event is defined as the facility ceasing operation or a change in ownership. The disposition of a taxpayer's interest in a qualified child care facility triggers recapture rules, unless the new owner agrees in writing to assume the recapture liability. The taxpayer's interest in a qualified child care facility triggers recapture rules, unless the new owner agrees to assume the recapture liability. The person acquiring the facility will be treated as the taxpayer for assessing any recapture liability, with special rules regarding tax benefits. The increase in tax under this subsection does not affect credits used to reduce tax liability. No credits can be used against the tax increase for determining the amount of any credit under subpart A, B, or D. The tax increase also does not apply to a cessation of operation of a qualified child care facility due to a casualty loss. The tax increase under this subsection does not apply to a cessation of operation of a qualified child care facility due to a casualty loss, if the loss is restored by reconstruction or replacement within a reasonable period. Special rules apply for aggregation of taxpayers, pass-thru in estates and trusts, and allocation in partnerships for the tax credit. Regulations prescribed by the Secretary for allocation of tax credit among partners in partnerships. No double benefit allowed, with reduction in basis of property if credit is determined. Basis reduction also applies in case of recapture amount determined for property. The credit determined under this section may result in a basis reduction for the property. If a recapture amount is determined for the property, the basis of the property shall be increased by the recapture amount. No other deductions or credits are allowed with respect to the credit determined under this section. The employer-provided child care credit under section 45D does not allow for any other deductions or credits under the tax code. This section will not apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include adding the employer-provided child care credit as a new paragraph under section 38(b). The employer-provided child care credit under section 45D is amended by adding a new paragraph. The table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 is also amended. The employer-provided child care credit under section 45D is amended for taxable years starting after December 31, 1996.
